questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a head injury. He is unconscious and is not able to open his eyes. He also has no verbal or motor responses. What will be his GCS score?
questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient will be 3. The lowest possible Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 3 and never zero.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

Eyes Opening

To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

Motor Response Score

Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimuli.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain. 

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the casualty ward with a history of road traffic accident and head trauma. She opens her eyes to pain, moans, can localize her limb towards the pain stimulus on the left hand and away from the pain stimulus on the right hand and both the legs are in extended posture. Calculate her GCS.
questions.solution:
The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of this patient is E2V2M5, which comes to a total score of 9.

  • E2 - Eye opens to pain
  • V2 - Moans
  • M5 - Localizes to pain on the left hand (the score represents the best performance elicited, which would be localized towards the pain stimulus)

questions.text: Which of the following head injury patients need not undergo head CT at this point in time?

choices.text: An RTA victim with GCS score of 12
A patient with an episode of vomiting
A child with an episode of seizure post-trauma
A biker with suspected skull fracture

questions.solution:
A single episode of vomiting after a head injury is not an indication for immediate CT brain. However, more than one episode mandates a scan.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A 26-year-old batsman was rushed to the ER when he fell unconscious after a cricket ball hit his head. He regained consciousness later but started to deteriorate rapidly. A plain CT of the patient is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect.

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. It lies behind the pterion, which is the thinnest part of the skull. 

In EDH, the patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the casualty after he was found lying near a ditch. He had a laceration over his scalp. His GCS on arrival was 13 and after a few minutes, it dropped to 10. A plain CT scan was done and given below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan showing a concavo-convex shaped hematoma on the left side with a midline shift to the right is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses.

The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands.

Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium for the past 6 hours. His wife reports him having a fall in the bathroom 4 weeks ago. On evaluation, the following funduscopic findings are noted. What will be your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and fundus examination are most probably suggestive of chronic subdural hematoma. The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema.

Chronic SDH is a collection of blood breakdown products that are at least 2 to 3 weeks old. It occurs in patients without a clear history of head trauma, as they may arise from a minor head injury. Alcoholics, the elderly, and patients on anticoagulation are at higher risk for developing chronic SDH than others.

Patients may present with headaches, seizures, confusion, contralateral hemiparesis, or coma. 

A chronic SDH >1 cm or any symptomatic SDH should be surgically drained.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a sudden onset severe headache and vomiting. His medical record revealed he has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. On examination, pulse - 100 bpm, BP - 190/110 mm Hg, marked neck rigidity was present and no neurological deficits were noted. What could be the most likely cause of the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm. It is an extrarenal manifestation of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. 

Clinical features of SAH:

  • Sudden-onset severe headache (thunderclap headache) 
  • Rapid onset vomiting
  • Confusion or a lowered level of consciousness
  • Seizures
  • Meningitic features of neck stiffness and photophobia often develop over hours.

The most common cause is trauma and is managed conservatively. The second most common cause is a rupture of a berry aneurysm.

CT scan is the investigation of choice. A hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid space. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region.

A lumbar puncture should be performed if the CT scan fails to establish the diagnosis of SAH. It will show xanthochromic CSF.

Delayed ischemic neurological deficit (DIND) is attributed to vasospasm of the cerebral vasculature typically developing 3–10 days following ictus. It is the main cause of a poor outcome.

Management:

  • Endovascular treatment ("coiling") is generally preferred over craniotomy and clipping for aneurysms amenable to this approach.
  • The combination of induced hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution (Triple-H therapy) is often utilized to prevent and treat cerebral vasospasm after aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

Note: The combination of subarachnoid hemorrhage and vitreous hemorrhage (subhyaloid) is known as Terson syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding delayed ischemic neurological deficit?

choices.text: It is seen in subarachnoid haemorrhage
It is attributed to cerebral vasospasm

questions.solution:
Delayed ischemic neurological deficit (DIND) usually occurs between 3 and 10 days after the SAH.

It is a delayed complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage characterized by the fluctuating decline in consciousness and appearance of neurological deficits. It is attributed to ischemia resulting from reactive cerebral vasospasm. Patients with a larger blood load (in the subarachnoid space) are at higher risk of vasospasm.

Medical management strategies aim to minimize secondary brain injury, through avoidance of hypoxia and hypotension and control of ICP.

The incidence of DIND can be lowered by prophylaxis with nimodipine (60 mg, 4 hourly) and hypervolemia (8 hourly normal saline).

questions.text: A 26-year-old formula one driver was rushed to the casualty, unconscious, following a heavy crash from a side-impact collision during a racing event. The CT scan was normal. However, MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages, especially in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain, with no midline shift. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a normal CT and MRI showing evidence of hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and midbrain is probably due to a diffuse axonal injury.

A diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration. Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.

Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. The prognosis is very poor.

MRI showing multiple hypointense punctate foci within the subcortical and deep white matter within the corpus callosum is characteristic of diffuse axonal injury.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours.

questions.text: According to the Glasgow Outcome Score, what score will you give to a patient who is in a persistent vegetative state following a head injury?
questions.solution:
A persistent vegetative state is given a score of 2, according to the Glasgow Outcome Score.

The Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) is different from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), and it is used to quantify the degree of recovery achieved after a head injury, especially for research purposes.

The scoring system is as follows:

Patient condition Score
Good recovery 5
Moderate disability 4
Severe disability 3
Persistent vegetative state 2
Dead 1

questions.text: A patient is recovering from a spinal shock after a fall from height. Which of the following is the first reflex that you will expect to reappear in him?
questions.solution:
Bulbocavernosus reflex is the first reflex to return after the spinal shock has resolved.

It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis in males and applying pressure to the clitoris or pulling the Foleys catheter in females. Any of these will lead to anal sphincter contraction.

Spinal shock is a condition of transient physiologic reflex depression of spinal cord function (motor, sensory, tone, reflexes) below the level of injury. It usually results from a high-impact, direct trauma to the spinal cord. When the level of injury is above T6, it can result in hemodynamic changes such as hypotension and bradycardia (due to loss of sympathetic tone and unopposed parasympathetic function).

The resolution of spinal shock occurs over a period of days to months, when the areflexia slowly transitions to hyperreflexia and spasticity. Reflexes return sequentially rather than simultaneously. The resolution of the somatic component of spinal shock is classically signaled by the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, a polysynaptic cutaneous spinal reflex (mediated by the conus medullaris) which is then followed by monosynaptic deep tendon reflexes (e.g. ankle jerk).

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for managing a patient with raised intracranial pressure following a head injury?
questions.solution:
Steroids are not used in severe head injury, since they are associated with increased mortality.

Initial management of raised intracranial pressure (ICP):

  • Airway protection 
  • Positioning the head up 20–30° (reverse Trendelenburg positioning)
  • A bolus of mannitol up to 1 g/kg for free water diuresis (the effect is delayed by 20 min)
  • Hypertonic saline (3% or 5%)
  • Maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance
  • Seizure control
  • Sedation using a combination of opiates and barbiturates
  • Ventriculostomy and/or craniectomy may be needed for definitive decompression.

ICP normally varies between 4 and 14 mmHg. Sustained ICP levels above 25 mmHg can injure the brain. The goal of therapy in raised ICP is to maintain the ICP 20 - 25 mmHg.

Note: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation through the foramen magnum compresses medullary vasomotor and respiratory centers, classically producing Cushing’s triad. It is comprised of:

  • Bradycardia
  • Raised blood pressure
  • Irregular respirations.

questions.text: In patients with head trauma, which of the following is least likely to cause secondary brain injuries?
questions.solution:
Hypercapnea (and not hypocapnea) is a cause of secondary brain injury. 

It is essential to avoid hypercapnia in patients with head injury since it will raise intracranial pressure (ICP). While hyperventilation is an effective way of managing acute intracranial hypertension, it should be remembered that it can produce a dangerous decrease in cerebral blood flow, especially if cerebral perfusion pressure is low. 

Primary brain injury (focal and diffuse) results from mechanical injury at the time of the trauma. Secondary brain injury is caused by the physiologic responses to the initial injury. This is thought to involve a cascade of events, with edema and hematomas leading to increased intracranial pressure, which leads to compression and deformation of surrounding brain tissue and further damage. 

 Causes of secondary brain injury:

  • Hypoxia
  • Hypotension
  • Raised ICP >20 mmHg
  • Low cerebral perfusion pressure
  • Hypercapnea
  • Hyperthermia
  • Seizures
  • Metabolic disturbance (hyperglycemia)

questions.text: A patient with a head injury presents to the casualty with rapidly deteriorating sensorium and progressive dilatation and fixation of the pupil. Neurosurgeon and CT scan are not available. The duty surgeon decides to make a burr hole. What will be the management plan?

choices.text: Make a hole in the temporal region, contralateral to the side of pupillary dilatation.
Make a hole in the midline, if both pupils are equal or it is not known which side dilated first.
If no localizing sign is found, make a hole in the left temporal region.
Refer to higher center if both pupils are equal or it is not known which side dilated first

questions.solution: In the given situation, no localizing sign is found and it is not known which side dilated first. So, the best choice would be to do a burr hole in the dominant hemisphere (most commonly, the left temporal region).

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding post-traumatic seizures in patients with head injury?

choices.text: Use of antiepileptics in late post-traumatic seizure patients is recommended
Prolonged seizures cause primary brain injury post head trauma
Occurrence of seizures after 2 weeks of head injury is called late post-traumatic seizures
Initiation of antiepileptics in early post traumatic seizure patients reduces the likelihood of developing post-traumatic epilepsy

questions.solution:
The use of antiepileptics in late post-traumatic seizure (PTS) patients is recommended. 

Post-traumatic seizures (PTS) are seizures that result from traumatic brain injury (TBI). They are classified into early and late. Early PTS occurs within 1 week and late PTS occurs after 1 week of trauma (Option C). 

Early PTS are acute symptomatic events, attributed to a direct reaction to injury and hemorrhage. Risk factors for early PTS are: 

  • Younger age (especially <5 years)
  • Moderate to severe head injury (measured by GCS)
  • Acute intracerebral hematoma
  • Subdural / Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Depressed skull fractures
  • Diffuse cerebral edema
  • History of alcohol abuse
  • Penetrating head injury

Late PTS usually occurs due to underlying permanent structural and physiologic changes within the brain. Patients with late PTS may develop post-traumatic epilepsy (PTE). It refers to recurrent and unprovoked PTS that occur at least 1 week after TBI. Risk factors for PTE are:

  • Early PTS
  • Severe head injury
  • Older age (especially >65 years)
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Intracranial hemorrhage
  • Intracranial infection
  • Abnormalities on EEG
  • Alcohol-related head injury

Prolonged seizures (30 to 60 minutes) can cause secondary brain injury, not primary (Option B). Hence, it is imperative to control acute seizures as soon as possible.

The initiation of antiepileptics in early PTS patients is to prevent damage due to seizures themselves. It does not reduce the likelihood of developing PTE (Option D). For patients who develop late PTS, because of the high risk of seizure recurrence after the first episode of late PTS, the use of antiepileptic medication is recommended even after a single late seizure episode. The long-term sequelae of head injury are headache, raised ICP, impaired short-term memory, lack of concentration, emotional disinhibition, and depression.

Prophylaxis for PTS is indicated in patients at risk of early PTS, for 7 days and is stopped without tapering the dose if no seizures have occurred during this duration. Prophylaxis is not recommended for late PTS.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding basilar skull fractures?

choices.text: Racoon eyes is one of the earliest signs to develop
Battle sign is associated with posterior cranial fossa fractures
CSF leaks should be promptly managed by surgical intervention
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided

questions.solution:
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided in patients with basilar skull fractures due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: “Halo” sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk for intracranial placement. NIPPV is avoided due to the risk for pneumocephalus.

The image below shows 'racoon' eyes.

 

The image below shows pneumocephalus.

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: A man is brought to the ER with a depressed skull fracture and a clean overlying scalp laceration. There are no focal neurological deficits. CT scan revealed that the degree of depression was less than the thickness of the adjacent skull bone. What is the next step in the management of the patient?

choices.text: Surgically elevate the depressed segment and close the laceration with sutures
Provide prophylactic antibiotics and discharge the patient
Apply dressing and discharge the patient

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the next step is to close the laceration with suture.

The management of the depressed skull fractures:

  • The first step is to order a CT scan to know the degree of depression and to exclude the presence of an intracranial hematoma or contusion.
  • The depressed fracture is elevated and managed as an open fracture (surgery) if:
    • The degree of depression is greater than the thickness of the adjacent skull
    • The wound is are open and grossly contaminated
    • There are focal neurological deficits
  • Less severe depressed fractures are managed by the closure of the overlying scalp laceration, if present.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player had a fall followed by one episode of vomiting, a day before his final match. When brought to the casualty, he was awake and conscious but could not recall events after the fall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Discharge home and advice adequate rest before playing the final match
Observe for 6 hours in the ED and refrain from playing for one week
Admit to intensive care for intracranial pressure monitoring

questions.solution:
The given history of fall and anterograde amnesia with no focal neurologic deficits points towards the diagnosis of concussion. Observation followed by a gradual return to play is the current recommendation for a concussion. 

It is defined as an alteration of consciousness as a result of closed head injury. It is the most common type of traumatic brain injury, which can result from vehicle accidents, falls, sports injuries, etc. 

Clinical features of concussion include:

  • Anterograde amnesia/post-traumatic amnesia - a hallmark of a concussion. In this type of amnesia, the events following the injury cannot be recalled.
  • Confusion
  • Headache
  • Dizziness
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting

Observation in the emergency department is essential following the clinical exam to look for alterations in mental status or focal neurological signs. The presence of either of which may signal more serious underlying pathology (e.g., intracranial bleeding).

Following discharge, the patients are advised to not return to contact sports e.g., football, boxing, etc. which carries the risk of further injury, for at least a week. Then, there should be a gradual, stepwise increase in physical activity.

Option A: There are no focal neurological deficits to warrant an NCCT of the brain.

Option B: Immediate discharge and return to intense physical activity following mild TBI are inappropriate. Because those who are symptomatic after a head injury, are vulnerable to a repeat impact. Due to disturbed cerebral autoregulation, even a minor second injury may trigger a form of malignant cerebral edema refractory to treatment.

Option D: Admission to the intensive care unit for intracranial pressure monitoring would be appropriate in patients with severe TBI, for which elevated intracranial pressure is a serious concern due to brain edema and/or bleeding. Severe TBI is characterized by a GCS ≤ 8. Here the patient has a GCS of >14.

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
